lessons.title: Safety
lessons.subtitle: Electrical, Antenna & RF Hazards

sections.title: Electrical Shock Hazards
sections.content: Current kills, not voltage alone. As little as 100 milliamps (0.1A) flowing through the body can be fatal. This is about the amount of current drawn by a small light bulb! Effects range from barely perceptible (1mA) to painful shock (5mA) to muscle contractions where you can't let go (10-20mA) to cardiac arrest (100mA+).
keyFacts: 100 mA can be fatal - remember this number for the exam
First aid: Turn OFF power first, then call 911, begin CPR if not breathing
Never touch a shock victim until power is disconnected

sections.title: Grounding & Circuit Protection
sections.content: Proper grounding provides a safe path for fault current. The green wire in a three-prong plug connects to the chassis - never remove or bypass it! Different devices protect different things: GFCI (Ground Fault Circuit Interrupter) protects PEOPLE by detecting when current goes where it shouldn't (trips at ~5mA). Fuses and circuit breakers protect EQUIPMENT from overcurrent - they're too slow to protect humans.
keyFacts: GFCI = protects people, Fuses/Breakers = protect equipment
Never bypass the ground prong on a three-prong plug

sections.title: Tower & Antenna Safety
sections.content: Tower work requires proper training and equipment. Never climb alone - always have a ground helper. Required gear includes: hard hat (protects from falling objects), safety harness (prevents falls), proper footwear, and two-way radio. Maintain 100% tie-off at all times. Power lines are extremely dangerous - maintain clearance of at least antenna height + 10 feet. Assume ALL wires are energized.
keyFacts: Never climb alone - ground helper required
Always use BOTH hard hat AND safety harness
Power line clearance: antenna height + 10 feet minimum

sections.title: Lightning Protection
sections.content: Lightning arrestors at the antenna feed point and proper grounding reduce damage risk, but nothing provides complete protection. The safest practice is to disconnect antenna feedlines and unplug equipment during electrical storms. Use heavy ground wire (#10 AWG or larger) connected to an 8-foot copper ground rod. Bond all grounds together at a single point.
keyFacts: Disconnect antennas during storms - safest practice
Lightning arrestors reduce but don't eliminate risk

sections.title: RF Radiation Safety
sections.content: RF radiation is non-ionizing - it causes tissue HEATING, not DNA damage like X-rays. The eyes are most vulnerable because they have poor blood flow to dissipate heat. MPE (Maximum Permissible Exposure) limits vary by frequency - the 30-300 MHz range has the LOWEST (most restrictive) limits. Duty cycle matters: a 100W transmitter at 50% duty cycle = 50W average power for MPE calculations.
keyFacts: RF causes heating (non-ionizing) - eyes most vulnerable
30-300 MHz has the most restrictive MPE limits
Reduce exposure: lower power, more distance, higher antenna, lower duty cycle

lessons.examTip: The three critical numbers: 100mA can kill, 30-300 MHz is most restrictive, and GFCI protects people while fuses protect equipment.

lessons.title: FCC Rules
lessons.subtitle: Licensing, Privileges & Regulations

sections.title: Licensing Basics
sections.content: Part 97 of FCC Rules governs amateur radio in the United States. Three license classes are currently issued: Technician, General, and Amateur Extra. Your license is valid for 10 years. After expiration, you have a 2-year grace period to renew - but you CANNOT transmit during the grace period! You can begin transmitting as soon as your license appears in the FCC database (no waiting for the paper copy).
keyFacts: 2-year grace period, but NO transmitting while expired
Can transmit as soon as license appears in FCC database

sections.title: Technician Privileges
sections.content: Technicians get FULL privileges on VHF/UHF bands (6 meters, 2 meters, 1.25 meters, 70 cm). On HF, Technicians have limited voice privileges on 10 meters only: 28.300-28.500 MHz with 200 watts PEP maximum. Above 30 MHz, maximum power is 1500 watts PEP. CW (Morse code) is allowed on additional frequencies.
keyFacts: Limited HF: 10 meters only (28.3-28.5 MHz), 200W max

sections.title: Station Identification
sections.content: You must identify your station at the END of each contact AND every 10 MINUTES during a contact. Use English or CW (Morse code) for identification. You may use tactical callsigns like 'Net Control' during operation, but you must still give your FCC callsign per the rules. You can add self-assigned indicators like '/mobile' or '/portable'.
keyFacts: ID at end of contact AND every 10 minutes during
Tactical calls OK, but still must give FCC callsign

sections.title: Prohibited Activities
sections.content: Several things are NOT allowed on amateur radio: obscene or indecent language, broadcasting (one-way transmissions to the general public), encryption (except for satellite/RC control commands), music (except incidental to manned spacecraft retransmission), and receiving payment for operating (except when teaching at an educational institution).
keyFacts: No obscene language, broadcasting, or encryption

sections.title: Control Operator & Interference
sections.content: Every amateur station must have a licensed control operator. The control operator is responsible for proper operation of the station. If you operate someone else's station, your privileges are limited to YOUR license class, not theirs. Willful interference is NEVER permitted under any circumstances. Keep your email address updated with the FCC or risk license suspension!
keyFacts: Control operator always required and responsible
Your privileges limited to YOUR license class

lessons.examTip: Key numbers: 10 years license, 2-year grace (no TX), 200W on HF, 1500W on VHF+. And willful interference is NEVER allowed!

lessons.title: Operating Procedures
lessons.subtitle: Repeaters, Nets & Emergency Comms

sections.title: Repeater Basics
sections.content: Repeaters extend your range by receiving your signal and retransmitting it at higher power from a better location. You transmit on the repeater's INPUT and listen on its OUTPUT. The difference is called the OFFSET. Standard offsets: 2 meters = ¬±600 kHz, 70 cm = ¬±5 MHz. Many repeaters require a CTCSS tone (also called PL tone) - a sub-audible tone that opens the repeater's squelch.
keyFacts: CTCSS/PL tone often required for access

sections.title: Simplex & Calling Frequencies
sections.content: Simplex means transmitting and receiving on the SAME frequency (no repeater). The national 2-meter FM simplex calling frequency is 146.520 MHz - memorize this! Use simplex when you can communicate directly - it leaves repeaters available for those who need them. The 'reverse' function on your radio lets you listen to the repeater's input to check if a station can reach it directly.
keyFacts: Simplex = same frequency TX and RX
Use simplex when possible to free up repeaters

sections.title: Making Contacts
sections.content: Before calling CQ (calling any station), LISTEN first to make sure the frequency is clear, then ask 'Is this frequency in use?' To call a specific station, say their callsign followed by yours: 'W1ABC, this is KB6NU.' When responding to a CQ, give your callsign followed by theirs. Q signals: QRM means interference from other stations, QSY means changing frequency.
keyFacts: Listen first, ask if frequency in use, then call

sections.title: Digital Repeaters (DMR)
sections.content: DMR (Digital Mobile Radio) uses 'talkgroups' - think of them as separate chat rooms on one repeater. You program your radio with a 'code plug' containing talkgroup IDs. You must also set the correct 'color code' (0-15) - similar to CTCSS tones for analog repeaters. DMR uses two time slots per frequency, doubling capacity.

sections.title: Emergency Communications
sections.content: ARES (Amateur Radio Emergency Service) is a volunteer organization. RACES (Radio Amateur Civil Emergency Service) operates under government authority during emergencies. Important: FCC rules ALWAYS apply, even during emergencies - there's no exemption. The ONLY exception is when there's immediate safety of life or protection of property, you may briefly operate outside your privileges.
keyFacts: FCC rules always apply, even in emergencies
Life safety exception exists for immediate emergencies

sections.title: Net Operations
sections.content: A net is an organized on-air meeting. The Net Control Station (NCS) directs all traffic - transmit only when called upon (except in emergencies). 'Traffic' means messages being passed. Good traffic handling means passing messages EXACTLY as received - don't interpret, edit, or add to them. Use the phonetic alphabet to spell unusual words clearly.
keyFacts: NCS directs traffic - wait to be called

lessons.examTip: Memorize: 146.520 MHz (2m simplex), 600 kHz (2m offset), 5 MHz (70cm offset). ARES=volunteer, RACES=government.

lessons.title: Radio Wave Propagation
lessons.subtitle: How Signals Travel

sections.title: Radio Wave Fundamentals
sections.content: Radio waves are electromagnetic waves with two components: an electric field and a magnetic field traveling at RIGHT ANGLES to each other. They travel at the speed of light: 300,000,000 meters per second (300 million m/s). Polarization is defined by the orientation of the ELECTRIC field.
keyFacts: Electric + magnetic fields at right angles

sections.title: Wavelength & Frequency
sections.content: Wavelength and frequency have an inverse relationship - higher frequency means shorter wavelength. The formula: Wavelength (meters) = 300 √∑ Frequency (MHz). Example: 146 MHz ‚Üí 300 √∑ 146 = 2.05 meters (that's why it's called the '2 meter band'). Frequency ranges: HF = 3-30 MHz, VHF = 30-300 MHz, UHF = 300-3000 MHz.
keyFacts: HF: 3-30 MHz, VHF: 30-300 MHz, UHF: 300-3000 MHz

sections.title: Line of Sight & VHF/UHF
sections.content: VHF/UHF signals travel mostly in straight lines (line-of-sight). They're blocked by Earth's curvature and don't bend around obstacles well. However, the radio horizon extends FARTHER than the visual horizon because the atmosphere slightly refracts (bends) radio waves. Higher antenna = greater range. Trees and vegetation ABSORB UHF and microwave signals.

sections.title: Multipath & Polarization
sections.content: Multipath occurs when signals arrive via multiple paths (direct + reflected), causing them to reinforce or cancel each other. Moving your antenna just a few feet can cause BIG signal changes. 'Picket fencing' is the rapid flutter heard on mobile VHF/UHF signals caused by multipath. For best results, both stations should use the SAME polarization: FM repeaters use VERTICAL, SSB/CW weak signal work uses HORIZONTAL.
keyFacts: Picket fencing = multipath flutter on mobile signals

sections.title: Special Propagation Modes
sections.content: Tropospheric ducting enables 300+ mile VHF/UHF contacts during temperature inversions. Sporadic E creates random ionization in the E layer, allowing short skip on 6m and 10m bands. Meteor scatter bounces signals off ionized meteor trails - works best on 6 METERS. Auroral backscatter reflects signals from the aurora (signals are distorted). Rain/snow decreases microwave range but has little effect on 10m and 6m.
keyFacts: Sporadic E: short skip on 6m and 10m

sections.title: HF Ionospheric Propagation
sections.content: The ionosphere (50-600 miles up) can refract HF signals back to Earth, enabling worldwide communication. VHF/UHF mostly passes through the ionosphere. Sunspots affect propagation - more sunspots = more ionization = better propagation on higher HF bands (6m, 10m). Best time for 10m DX: dawn to shortly after sunset during high sunspot activity.
keyFacts: HF bounces off ionosphere for long-distance

lessons.examTip: Key formula: Œª = 300/MHz. Meteor scatter = 6 meters. VHF/UHF = line-of-sight. 30-300 MHz = VHF range.

lessons.title: Amateur Radio Practices
lessons.subtitle: Station Setup & Controls

sections.title: Computer Interfaces
sections.content: A sound card interface (like SignaLink or RigBlaster) connects your computer to your radio for digital modes like FT8, PSK31, etc. It provides: audio IN (from radio receiver), audio OUT (to radio transmitter), and PTT control (push-to-talk switching). This allows your computer software to send and receive data through your radio.
keyFacts: Sound card interface connects computer to radio
Provides audio in/out plus PTT control
Required for digital modes (FT8, PSK31, etc.)

sections.title: SWR Meters & Measurement
sections.content: An SWR meter connects BETWEEN the transceiver and antenna (in the feedline). It measures the ratio of forward power to reflected power, showing how well your antenna system is matched. SWR of 1:1 = perfect match (all power to antenna). Higher SWR means power is being reflected back to your transmitter, which can cause damage and reduced performance.
keyFacts: SWR meter goes BETWEEN radio and antenna
High SWR = power reflected, possible damage

sections.title: Squelch & Noise Control
sections.content: Squelch MUTES the receiver when no signal is present - it silences the annoying background hiss. Set it by turning squelch all the way down (hear noise), then slowly increasing until the noise just stops. If squelch is too tight, you'll miss weak signals. Types: carrier squelch (any signal opens it), tone squelch/CTCSS (only matching tone opens it).
keyFacts: Squelch mutes receiver when no signal present

sections.title: RIT & Tuning Controls
sections.content: RIT (Receiver Incremental Tuning) adjusts your RECEIVE frequency WITHOUT changing your transmit frequency. Use it when another station is slightly off frequency - you can tune them in while keeping your transmit frequency where others expect it. Remember: RIT = Receive changes only, Transmit stays the same.
keyFacts: RIT = Receive changes, Transmit stays same
Use when other station is slightly off frequency

sections.title: VOX & Hands-Free Operation
sections.content: VOX (Voice Operated Transmit) automatically switches to transmit when you speak into the microphone - no need to press the PTT button. Great for contesting, taking notes, or mobile operation. VOX delay controls how long the radio stays in transmit after you stop speaking. Anti-VOX prevents your speaker audio from triggering transmit.
keyFacts: VOX delay = time before returning to receive

sections.title: Filters, VFOs & Split Operation
sections.content: Narrower filter bandwidth means less interference from adjacent signals (but also less audio fidelity). Dual VFO lets you monitor TWO frequencies simultaneously. Split operation means transmit and receive on DIFFERENT frequencies - common for DX pileups where the DX station says 'listening up 5' (meaning transmit 5 kHz higher than their frequency).
keyFacts: Split = TX and RX on different frequencies

sections.title: Antenna Tuner
sections.content: An antenna tuner (coupler) matches your antenna system to your transceiver so the transmitter sees the proper load. Important: it does NOT fix antenna or feedline problems - it only masks them from the transmitter. Losses still exist in the antenna system. Always use minimum power necessary for communication (FCC rule).
keyFacts: Does NOT fix antenna problems - only masks them

lessons.examTip: RIT = Receive only changes. SWR meter goes BETWEEN radio and antenna. VOX = voice-activated transmit.

lessons.title: Electrical Principles
lessons.subtitle: Ohm's Law, Power & Math

sections.title: Voltage, Current & Resistance
sections.content: Think of electricity like water in a pipe. VOLTAGE (E) is the pressure pushing electrons - measured in Volts. CURRENT (I) is the flow rate of electrons - measured in Amperes (Amps). RESISTANCE (R) is opposition to flow (like a narrow pipe section) - measured in Ohms. These three are related by Ohm's Law.

sections.title: Ohm's Law
sections.content: The fundamental formula: E = I √ó R (Voltage = Current √ó Resistance). Rearranged: I = E/R (to find current) or R = E/I (to find resistance). Example: 12V across 4 ohms = 12√∑4 = 3 Amps. Important: always convert milliamps (mA) to Amps before calculating (divide by 1000).
keyFacts: Convert mA to A before calculating (√∑1000)

sections.title: Power Calculations
sections.content: Power formula: P = I √ó E (Power = Current √ó Voltage). Remember 'PIE'! Power is measured in Watts. Rearranged: I = P/E (to find current) or E = P/I (to find voltage). Combined formulas: P = E¬≤/R or P = I¬≤√óR. Example: 13.8V √ó 10A = 138 Watts.
keyFacts: Also: P = E¬≤/R and P = I¬≤√óR

sections.title: Metric Prefixes
sections.content: Large numbers: Giga (G) = billion (1,000,000,000), Mega (M) = million (1,000,000), kilo (k) = thousand (1,000). Small numbers: milli (m) = 1/1,000, micro (Œº) = 1/1,000,000, pico (p) = 1/1,000,000,000,000. Move the decimal 3 places for each prefix step. Example: 28,400 kHz = 28.4 MHz.
keyFacts: Move decimal 3 places per prefix step

sections.title: Conductors & Insulators
sections.content: CONDUCTORS have LOW resistance - electrons flow easily. Good conductors: copper, aluminum (used for wires). INSULATORS have HIGH resistance - they block electron flow. Good insulators: glass, rubber, plastic (used for wire coatings). DC (Direct Current) flows in one direction. AC (Alternating Current) reverses direction periodically (wall outlets = 60 Hz AC).

sections.title: Decibels
sections.content: Decibels (dB) are a logarithmic way to express power ratios. Key values to memorize: +3 dB = DOUBLE the power, -3 dB = HALF the power, +10 dB = TEN times the power. So +6 dB = 4√ó power (double twice). Standard amateur radio impedance is 50 ohms.
keyFacts: +3 dB = double power, -3 dB = half power

lessons.examTip: Memorize: E=IR and P=IE (PIE). +3dB = 2√ó power, +10dB = 10√ó power. Standard impedance = 50 ohms.

lessons.title: Electronic Components
lessons.subtitle: Resistors, Capacitors, Semiconductors

sections.title: Resistors
sections.content: A resistor OPPOSES current flow - like a narrow section in a pipe. Measured in Ohms. Types include fixed (set value) and variable (adjustable). A potentiometer is a variable resistor used for volume controls, etc. Resistors have power (wattage) ratings - exceed the rating and they'll overheat and possibly catch fire! Color bands indicate resistance value.

sections.title: Capacitors
sections.content: A capacitor stores energy in an ELECTRIC FIELD between two conductive plates. Measured in Farads (usually microfarads ŒºF or picofarads pF). Key behavior: capacitors BLOCK DC but PASS AC. They charge up to DC voltage then stop current, but AC constantly changes so current flows. Electrolytic capacitors are polarized - connect backwards and they can explode!

sections.title: Inductors
sections.content: An inductor (coil of wire) stores energy in a MAGNETIC FIELD. Measured in Henrys (usually millihenrys mH or microhenrys ŒºH). Key behavior: inductors BLOCK AC (high frequencies) but PASS DC. They're the OPPOSITE of capacitors! Used in RF chokes, filters, and transformers. A transformer is two coupled inductors that step voltage up or down.
keyFacts: Blocks AC, passes DC (opposite of capacitor!)

sections.title: Diodes
sections.content: A diode allows current to flow in ONE direction only - like a one-way valve. Has an anode (+) and cathode (-). Forward bias = current flows (positive to anode). Main use: rectifiers that convert AC to DC. LED (Light Emitting Diode) emits light when current flows. Zener diode maintains constant voltage (voltage regulator).
keyFacts: Allows current in ONE direction only
Rectifier use: converts AC to DC
LED = emits light, Zener = voltage regulator

sections.title: Transistors
sections.content: A transistor can AMPLIFY signals or act as a SWITCH. Small input controls large output. Two main types: BJT (Bipolar Junction Transistor) has Base, Collector, Emitter - small base current controls large collector-emitter current. FET (Field Effect Transistor) has Gate, Drain, Source - gate voltage controls drain-source current. BJT = current-controlled, FET = voltage-controlled.

sections.title: Integrated Circuits
sections.content: An IC (Integrated Circuit) contains many components on a SINGLE semiconductor chip - can have millions of transistors! Types include analog (op-amps), digital (microprocessors), and mixed-signal. Voltage regulator ICs (like 7805 = 5V, 7812 = 12V) maintain constant output voltage. ICs are sensitive to static discharge (ESD) - use anti-static precautions when handling.

lessons.examTip: Capacitor blocks DC/passes AC. Inductor blocks AC/passes DC - they're OPPOSITES! BJT = B/C/E, FET = G/D/S.

lessons.title: Practical Circuits
lessons.subtitle: Equipment & Troubleshooting

sections.title: Receivers & Transmitters
sections.content: A transceiver combines transmitter and receiver in one unit. Key receiver specs: Sensitivity = ability to detect WEAK signals, Selectivity = ability to REJECT adjacent signals (discriminate between signals). Most modern amateur radios use the superheterodyne design, where a mixer converts the incoming RF to a fixed IF (Intermediate Frequency) for processing.

sections.title: Software Defined Radio (SDR)
sections.content: SDR uses SOFTWARE to perform functions traditionally done in hardware - filtering, modulation, demodulation, mixing. Advantages include flexibility (software updates), multiple modes with same hardware, wideband reception, and visual spectrum displays. A DMR hotspot connects a digital radio to the internet for worldwide access to DMR networks.
keyFacts: Software processes signals instead of hardware
DMR hotspot = internet gateway for digital

sections.title: Common Problems
sections.content: Overmodulation (mic gain too high) causes distorted audio and 'splatter' on adjacent frequencies. RF feedback happens when RF gets into audio circuits - fix with better grounding and ferrite chokes. Fundamental overload is interference from very strong nearby signals overwhelming the receiver. Low battery in handhelds causes reduced power and distorted audio.
keyFacts: RF feedback: fix with grounding, ferrite chokes

sections.title: Interference Solutions
sections.content: RFI (Radio Frequency Interference) to home electronics is often fixed with FERRITE CHOKES (snap-on ferrites) on device cables - they block RF picked up by wiring. A LOW-PASS FILTER between transmitter and antenna reduces harmonic radiation that can interfere with other services. Harmonics are multiples of your fundamental frequency (7 MHz ‚Üí 14 MHz 2nd harmonic ‚Üí 21 MHz 3rd harmonic).
keyFacts: Ferrite chokes on cables block RFI

sections.title: Test Equipment
sections.content: Multimeter measures voltage, current, and resistance - essential for troubleshooting. Oscilloscope shows signal waveforms visually - checks modulation, finds distortion. Frequency counter precisely measures frequency. SWR meter shows how well antenna is matched (1:1 = perfect). Antenna analyzer measures SWR and impedance WITHOUT transmitting - safer for testing.

sections.title: SWR & Dummy Loads
sections.content: SWR (Standing Wave Ratio) measures impedance match quality. 1:1 = perfect match (all power to antenna), below 2:1 = acceptable, above 3:1 = concerning (significant reflected power, possible damage). A dummy load is a 50Œ© NON-INDUCTIVE resistor that dissipates RF as heat - use for testing transmitters without radiating a signal.
keyFacts: Non-inductive to work at RF frequencies

lessons.examTip: SWR 1:1 is perfect. Ferrite chokes solve RFI. Sensitivity = weak signals, Selectivity = adjacent signals.

lessons.title: Signals & Emissions
lessons.subtitle: Modulation, Digital & Satellites

sections.title: Modulation Types
sections.content: FM (Frequency Modulation): voice varies the FREQUENCY of the carrier. Wider bandwidth (~15 kHz) but better noise immunity. Used on VHF/UHF. SSB (Single Sideband): most efficient for voice, narrow bandwidth (~2.8 kHz), no carrier transmitted. Preferred for HF long-distance. CW (Morse Code): on/off keying, NARROWEST bandwidth (~150 Hz), most efficient mode.
keyFacts: SSB: most efficient voice, ~2.8 kHz bandwidth

sections.title: Bandwidth Comparison
sections.content: From narrowest to widest: CW (~150 Hz) ‚Üí FT8 (~50 Hz!) ‚Üí RTTY (~250 Hz) ‚Üí SSB (~2.8 kHz) ‚Üí AM (~6 kHz) ‚Üí FM (~15 kHz). FT8 is incredibly narrow - only 50 Hz bandwidth! This allows it to work with very weak signals, even 20 dB below the noise floor.
keyFacts: CW narrowest (~150 Hz), FM widest (~15 kHz)

sections.title: Digital Modes
sections.content: FT8: Popular weak-signal digital mode with 15-second transmit/receive cycles. Only 50 Hz bandwidth, works with signals buried in noise. APRS (Automatic Packet Reporting System): combines packet radio with GPS for position reporting. Uses 144.390 MHz in North America. Winlink: email via radio - critical for emergency communications.
keyFacts: FT8: 15-second cycles, works below noise floor
Winlink: email via radio for emergencies

sections.title: Amateur Satellites
sections.content: Most amateur satellites are LEO (Low Earth Orbit) - 100-1200 miles up with short pass times (10-20 minutes). Uplink = frequency TO the satellite, Downlink = frequency FROM the satellite. Doppler shift: frequency appears higher as satellite approaches, lower as it recedes - must adjust frequencies during a pass.
keyFacts: LEO satellites: short pass times (10-20 min)
Uplink = to satellite, Downlink = from satellite

sections.title: Satellite Operating
sections.content: Use MINIMUM power necessary - satellites have sensitive receivers and you don't want to capture the whole transponder. Listen first to find your own downlink signal before calling. Full duplex operation lets you hear yourself through the satellite. Keep transmissions brief - many stations share limited pass time. Directional antennas (Yagi) greatly improve performance.
keyFacts: Use minimum power - satellites are sensitive
Keep transmissions brief - share the pass

sections.title: Station Setup for Digital
sections.content: Digital modes need: a sound card interface (connects radio audio to computer), software for the mode you want to use, and accurate computer clock (essential for FT8). CAT (Computer Aided Transceiver) control lets software control the radio. Watch audio levels carefully - too high causes distortion and splatter.
keyFacts: Accurate computer time essential for FT8

lessons.examTip: Bandwidth order: CW (narrowest) ‚Üí SSB ‚Üí FM (widest). FT8 = 50 Hz, 15-second cycles. APRS = 144.390 MHz.

lessons.title: Antennas & Feed Lines
lessons.subtitle: Antenna Types, Coax & Connectors

sections.title: Dipole Antennas
sections.content: The half-wave dipole is the fundamental antenna. Length formula: Length (feet) = 468 √∑ Frequency (MHz). Example: 468 √∑ 7.15 MHz = 65.5 feet for 40m band. Characteristics: ~73 ohms impedance at center feed point, bidirectional radiation pattern (figure-8), horizontal polarization. Simple to build and very effective!

sections.title: Vertical Antennas
sections.content: Vertical antennas produce VERTICAL polarization and have an OMNIDIRECTIONAL pattern (360¬∞ in horizontal plane). Quarter-wave vertical has ~36Œ© impedance. 5/8-wave vertical has MORE GAIN than 1/4-wave - better for VHF/UHF mobile because of lower radiation angle. Verticals take less horizontal space and are good for mobile/portable use.
keyFacts: Good for mobile - less horizontal space needed

sections.title: Yagi (Beam) Antennas
sections.content: Yagi is a directional gain antenna - must be aimed at the station you want to work. Three element types: REFLECTOR (longest, behind driven element, reflects signal forward), DRIVEN element (connected to feedline, ~1/2 wavelength), DIRECTOR(S) (shortest, in front, directs signal forward). Adding more directors increases gain but narrows the beam.
keyFacts: More directors = more gain, narrower beam

sections.title: Antenna Gain
sections.content: Antenna gain is measured in dBi (vs isotropic - theoretical point source) or dBd (vs dipole). Conversion: dBi = dBd + 2.15. A dipole has 2.15 dBi gain (0 dBd by definition). A 3-element Yagi might have 7 dBi gain. Higher gain means energy is concentrated in a narrower beam - you're not creating power, just focusing it.
keyFacts: dBi = gain vs isotropic, dBd = gain vs dipole

sections.title: Coaxial Cable
sections.content: Coax has a center conductor, dielectric insulator, shield/braid, and outer jacket. Common types: RG-213/RG-8 = low loss (thick, good for long runs), RG-58 = higher loss (thin, flexible, short runs only). Feed line loss INCREASES with higher frequency and longer cable length. Protect outdoor coax from UV damage.
keyFacts: RG-213: low loss (thick), RG-58: higher loss (thin)
Loss increases with frequency and length

sections.title: Connectors & SWR
sections.content: Common connectors: PL-259/SO-239 (standard for HF, not weatherproof - seal outdoors), Type N (better for VHF/UHF, weatherproof, lower loss), BNC (quick-connect, common on handhelds), SMA (small, common on HTs). SWR: 1:1 = perfect match, below 2:1 = acceptable, above 3:1 = concerning. Match polarization between stations for best signal!
keyFacts: PL-259: HF standard. Type N: VHF/UHF, weatherproof

lessons.examTip: Dipole formula: 468/MHz. Yagi: Reflector=longest, Director=shortest. dBi = dBd + 2.15. PL-259 for HF, Type N for VHF/UHF.
